Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Stability of Structures Large and Small
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports collaborative research efforts in the area of materials science by an interdisciplinary team comprising pure mathematicians, applied mathematicians, computer scientists, and physicists. Answers to natural questions about the stability and rigidity of material structures involve understanding the geometry of their components. Recent advances in materials synthesis have emphasized the need for a deeper understanding of the geometric stability of physical structures at the atomic scale and the need for insight at all scales, from atomic to macroscopic. Key mathematical tools for this analysis come from the area of "rigidity theory," which studies the mathematical properties of discrete sets of points with the distances between certain pairs of points held fixed or constrained by distance inequalities. Rigidity theory lies at the nexus of discrete geometry, graph theory, and algorithms, and it has deep connections to semidefinite programming and convex geometry. This project aims to deepen understanding of the stability of material structures.

One goal of this project is to develop a mechanistic explanation of tunneling between asymmetric stable configurations of two-dimensional disordered materials, such as glass. Construction of accurate mechanistic and computational models requires deep mathematical analysis and development of appropriate algorithms. A second goal is to develop methods for predicting the stability, configurational entropy, and kinetics of small short-ranged-potential systems in three dimensions. Examples of such distance-constraint systems include small molecular structures, as well as colloidal clusters, containing a few particles bound together by reversible attractive interactions, modeled as sticky spheres. What kinds of rigid configurations are there, and what are computationally feasible tests for their rigidity? How do these particles move and the structures deform? There is a tight link between rigidity theory and the general convexity and duality properties of the positive semidefinite cone, a central concept in numerical optimization. Finding a recursive decomposition of a generically rigid framework into rigid subsystems is a longstanding problem. Additionally, matroid theory, important in rigidity theory, has made the characterization of rigid systems more approachable and more algorithmically efficient. Rigidity theory could have implications for algorithms for low-rank matrix completion as well. These connections, questions, and implications will be explored in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many unsolved puzzles in solid-state and soft-matter physics arise from poor mechanistic understanding of energetic and entropic processes at the nano and micro scales. While molecular dynamics, Monte carlo simulations and other data-intensive inference-based models can inform, comprehensive theory-building requires an understanding of the complex geometric and topological structure of high dimensional configuration spaces where these processes "take place." This collaborative project between a physicist, pure and applied mathematicians and theoretical computer scientists at 5 academic institutions has used a scale-independent, geometric constraints perspective to develop such structural and computational models and opensource software, while solving problems of independent mathematical interest in combinatorial and geometric rigidity, distance geometry, real-algebraic geometry and their algorithmic foundations.

Significant contributions include the following. 

(a) Multiple algorithms for enumerating (stable)  configurations or realizations of input glassy isostatic or minimally rigid networks, as well as sticky-sphere assemblies computing distance measures between them,  and tracking how their number varies with key input parameters. These illuminate tunnelling and rare events in the energy landscapes of glasses as well as colloidal particles, amphiphiles, polymer vescicles etc.

(b)  One corollary is the formalization of a notion of realization type that enables a polynomial time algorithm for computing a given realization type of a planar linkage (graph with edge lengths specified) if it exists. Determining existence and enumeration of such realizations have NP-hard and exponential time complexity respectively. The algorithm generalizes well-known algorithms for recursive decomposition of graphs into maximal rigid subgraphs to non-rigid subgraphs. The resulting flex-DR-plans are used to specify the realization type as well as to search for and find realizations by using Cayley or distance based parameterizations. These are branched covers that convexify constrained configuration spaces and hence make search tractable while avoiding gradient descent and other methods to enforce the constraints, and ensuring efficient  computation of the inverse of the parameterization. 

(c) Another corollary is an algorithm for computing low energy paths between stable configurations, as well as path probabilities in sticky-sphere assemblies by novel  applications of semi-algebraic geometry concepts including dimensional (energy-level) stratification and again  convexification using Cayley or distance parameters, all of which are adapted to symmetries of the configuration space arising from identical assembling spheres. These are implemented as SymEASAL, an opensource software suite built atop the more general EASAL Efficient Atlasing and Seach of Assembly Landscapes, curated in the ACM Transactions of Mathematical Software collection.

(d) A rigorous characterization of "almost rigidity" in the hierarchy of rigidity concepts from infinitesimal and first order rigidity, second-order rigidity and prestress stability.

(e) A connection of circle packing with traditional bar-joint rigidity, confirming  a working assumption underlying  the algorithms in (c).

(f) A simpler constructive proof and generalization of the celebrated Koebe Andreev Thurston theorem leading to a circle packing algorithm as a "(diagonal) flip and flow" diffeomorphism.

(g) A significant improvement for computing shortest (diagonal) flip paths in lattice triangulations using a structural characterization based on the number-theoretic notion of Farey sequences, with potential applications in modeling Stone-Wales defect-based crack formations in graphene, glasses and  and 2D crystalline or structured materials as a discrete geometry based mechanistic alternative to  prevailing finite element simulations.
